{{use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} '''Fourteen Words''', '''14''', or '''14/88''', is a reference to the fourteen-word slogan “'''We must secure the existence of our people and a future for white children''',” or less commonly "Because the beauty of the White Aryan woman must not perish from the earth."{{cite book| first = Mattias| last = Gardell| title = Gods of the Blood: The Pagan Revival and White Separatism| page = 69}} The slogans were originally coined by [[White supremacy|white supremacist]] [[David Lane (white supremacist)|David Lane]],{{cite journal|last=Michael|first=George|year=2009|title=David Lane and the Fourteen Words|journal=Totalitarian Movements and Political Religions|volume=10|issue=1|pages=43–61|doi=10.1080/14690760903067986|issn=1469-0764}} a founding member of the [[Terrorism|terrorist]] organization [[The Order (white supremacist group)|The Order]].{{Cite book|title=Modern American Extremism and Domestic Terrorism: An Encyclopedia of Extremists and Extremist Groups|last=Balleck|first=Barry|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|year=2018|isbn=978-1440852749|location=[[United States]]|page=4}} The terms were coined while he was serving a 190-year sentence in [[federal prison]] for his role in violating the civil rights of [[Jews|Jewish]] talk show host [[Alan Berg]], who was murdered by another member of the group in June 1984.{{cite web|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/white-hate-group-campaign-of-menace-rise-above-movement|title=Racist, Violent, Unpunished: A White Hate Group's Campaign of Menace|last1=Thompson|first1=A.C.|date=19 October 2017|publisher=propublica.org|accessdate=20 October 2017}} The slogans were publicized through now-defunct [[Wotansvolk|14 Word Press]], founded in 1995 by Lane's wife to disseminate her husband's writings.{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/individual/david-lane|title=David Lane|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center}}{{cite web |title=David Lane |url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/individual/david-lane |publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center |accessdate=10 August 2018}} Lane also used the phrasing in other pamphlets including the "14 points" of his [[White genocide conspiracy theory|White Genocide Manifesto]] and further in his [[88 Precepts]] essay, stressing his support for racial and [[ethnic religion]]s, opposition to [[Multiracialism|universalism]], his opposition to [[miscegenation]], his [[anti-Americanism]], and support for [[racial segregation|racial separatism]].{{cite book|title=Werwolf!: The History of the National Socialist Guerrilla Movement, 1944–1946|last=Biddiscombe|first=Perry|publisher=University of Toronto Press |year=1998|isbn=978-0-8020-0862-6 |at=note 58}}{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/the-truth-about-88-new-book-reveals-secret-meaning-of-neo-nazi-codes-a-770820.html|title=The Truth about 88: New Book Reveals Secret Meaning of Neo-Nazi Codes|date=June 27, 2011|work=[[Spiegel Online]]|accessdate=8 January 2017}} According to the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]], the Fourteen Words slogan is derived from a passage in [[Adolf Hitler]]'s autobiographical book ''[[Mein Kampf]]'', {{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/group/american-freedom-party |title=The American Freedom Party (formerly American Third Position) is a political party initially established by racist Southern California skinheads that aims to deport immigrants and return the United States to white rule. |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}} and since the rise of the [[Alt-Right]], the Fourteen Words have become a popular Alt-Right meme{{cite web|title=14 Words, Know Your Meme|url=https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/14-words |publisher=Know Your Meme|accessdate=2018-11-29}}. == Phrasing == The terms were later adopted by [[white supremacist]]s and [[Neo-Nazism|neo-nazis]], [[white nationalist]]s and [[identitarians]], members of the [[far-right]] and [[alt-right]], the most widely used variation being:
We must secure the existence of our people and a future for white children.{{cite book|last1=Dunbar|first1=Edward|last2=Blanco|first2=Amalio|last3=Crèvecoeur-MacPhail |first3=Desirée A.|title=The Psychology of Hate Crimes as Domestic Terrorism: U.S. and Global Issues|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8GZoDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA91 |date=2016-11-21 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=9781440839078 |pages=91– |accessdate=8 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=Hate on Display: 14 words|url=http://www.adl.org/combating-hate/hate-on-display/c/14-words.html |publisher=Anti-Defamation League|accessdate=2007-06-01}}{{cite book|last1=Carmichael|first1=Cathie|last2=Maguire|first2=Richard C.|title=The Routledge History of Genocide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6rvlCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA211 |date=2015-05-01 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781317514848 |pages=211– |accessdate=8 January 2017}}
Another less commonly used variation is:
Because the beauty of the White Aryan woman must not perish from the earth.{{cite book| first = Mattias| last = Gardell| title = Gods of the Blood: The Pagan Revival and White Separatism| page = 69}}
It is sometimes combined with [[88 (number)#In white nationalism|88]], as in "14/88" or "1488" with the 8s representing the eighth letter of the alphabet (H), with "HH" standing for "[[Heil Hitler]]",{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/life/2017/01/dictionary-of-white-supermacist-slang-symbols/|title=A Complete Dictionary of White Supremacist Slang and Symbols|last=Ruiz|first=Stephen|date=January 11, 2017|publisher=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=May 30, 2018}} or simply as a reference to Lane's [[88 Precepts]],{{cite news |author=James Ridgeway |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/uselectionroadtrip/2008/oct/28/uselections-obama-racism |title=Fourteen Words that spell racism |date=28 October 2008 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}} which when combined with "14" refer to Lane's white supremacist [[neo-pagan]] religion, [[Wotansvolk|Wotanism]].{{cite web |author=Stephen Ruiz |url=https://www.complex.com/life/2017/01/dictionary-of-white-supermacist-slang-symbols/numbers-abbreves-acronyms-one |title=A Complete Dictionary of White Supremacist Slang and Symbols |publisher=Complex}} The slogan has been used in acts of white supremacist [[terrorism]] and [[violence]]. It was central to the symbolism of 2008's [[Barack Obama assassination plot in Tennessee|Barack Obama assassination plot]],{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/28/us/politics/28plot.html|title=Arrests in Plan to Kill Obama and Black Schoolchildren|last=Lichtblau|first=Eric|date=October 27, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=8 January 2017}} which intended to kill 88 [[African Americans]], including future President [[Barack Obama]] (at that time the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] nominee), 14 of whom were to be [[Decapitation|beheaded]].{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/Vote2008/story?id=6122962&page=1|title=Feds thwart alleged Obama assassination plot|last=Date|first=Jack|date=2008-10-27|newspaper=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=2008-10-28|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030022717/http://www.abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/Vote2008/story?id=6122962&page=1|archivedate=30 October 2008 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/10272008/news/nationalnews/the_plot_to_kill_obama_135558.htm|title=ATF stops plot to kill Barack Obama|last=Haberman|first=Maggie |authorlink=Maggie Haberman|date=2008-10-27|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081028183217/http://www.nypost.com/seven/10272008/news/nationalnews/the_plot_to_kill_obama_135558.htm|archivedate=2008-10-28|deadurl=yes}} Skinhead [[Curtis Allgier]] notably [[Tattoo|tattooed]] the words on to his body after he [[murder|murdered]] corrections officer Stephen Anderson,{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2007/08/23/face-hate-curtis-allgier-explained|title=Face of Hate: Curtis Allgier|last=Sanchez|first=Casey|date=August 23, 2007|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=May 30, 2018}} and [[Dylan Roof]]'s [[race war]]-inspired [[Charleston church shooting]] was influenced by the slogan. == Origins == [[File:Mein Kampf dust jacket.jpeg|thumb|Scholars say the slogan was influenced by [[Adolf Hitler]]'s ''[[Mein Kampf]]'', which was also written from prison]] A strong resemblance of the first definition to a statement in Adolf Hitler's ''[[Mein Kampf]]'' has been pointed out, albeit not by Lane or by Fourteen Word Press. Scholars such as Barry Balleck have stated that Lane was almost certainly influenced by Hitler, specifically the following statement in ''Mein Kampf''.
What we must fight for is to safeguard the existence and reproduction of our race and our people, the sustenance of our children and the purity of our blood, the freedom and independence of the fatherland, so that our people may mature for the fulfillment of the mission allotted it by the creator of the universe. Every thought and every idea, every doctrine and all knowledge, must serve this purpose. And everything must be examined from this point of view and used or rejected according to its utility. ''(Vol. I, Chapter 8)''
== Advocates == === United Kingdom === *[[Nick Griffin]], a British politician, former [[British National Party]] leader and [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]], has stated his political idealogy can summed up by the Fourteen Words.{{cite news |author=Dominic Gover |url=https://www.ibtimes.co.uk/bnp-leader-nick-griffin-slurred-jews-paki-police-officers-while-his-house-was-searched-1447553 |title=BNP Leader Nick Griffin Slurred 'Jews and Paki' Police Officers While His House Was Searched |date=7 May 2014 |publisher=[[International Business Times]]}} He has claimed "everything I do is related to building a nationalist movement through which [...] those 14 words can be carried out."{{cite news |author=Nick Griffin |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/may/06/nick-griffin-vision-bnp-britain-1990s-police-interviews |title=Nick Griffin's vision for BNP-led Britain shown in 1990s police interviews |date=6 May 2014 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}} *[[Colin Jordan]] (1923–2009), a leading figure in post-war [[neo-Nazism]] in Great Britain and longtime supporter of the 14 Words; contributed to Lane's book "Deceived, Damned & Defiant".Colin Jordan and Britain's Neo-Nazi Movement: Hitler's Echo, Page 230 *[[Millennial Woes]], a Scottish alt-right, neoreactionary political activist and YouTube personality, supports the slogan and has stated in 2017 that the "14 words used to be more controversial than they are nowadays". [[Faith Goldy]] has claimed that he had encouraged her to recite the slogan in an interview. *[[John Tyndall (politician)|John Tyndall]] (1934–2005), was a British [[Fascism|fascist]] political activist, who supported the Fourteen Words, along with his party The [[National Front (UK)|National Front]],{{cite news |author=Simon Childs |url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/wd7p75/dover-nazi-march-against-refugees-753 |title=We Watched Nazis Fight Anti-Fascists in England on Saturday |date=14 September 2015 |publisher=[[Vice Media]]}} which he was chairman of from 1972 to 1974.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-13048754 |title=Scottish election: National Front profile |date=13 April 2011 |publisher=BBC News}} === United States === *[[Andrew Anglin]], an American white supremacist and founder of ''[[The Daily Stormer]]'' website, frequently uses, references, and supports the slogan,{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/individual/andrew-anglin |title=Andrew Anglin |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}} and has claimed, "We care not for our own egos or lives. We care only about the agenda, which is: We must secure the existence of our people and a future for white children."{{cite web|url=https://www.adl.org/blog/richard-spencer-is-making-common-cause-with-neo-nazis |title=Richard Spencer Is Making Common Cause with Neo-Nazis |date=20 December 2016 |publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]]}} *[[Baked Alaska (entertainer)|Baked Alaska]], an American alt-right/far right social media personality, supports the words but not their creator, and has stated that there's "nothing wrong" with the slogan. Distancing himself from its creator, he claimed, "Just because others have used them doesn't change the meaning."{{cite web |author=Matt Novak |url=https://gizmodo.com/how-to-tell-if-youre-a-neo-nazi-1797849935 |title=How to Tell If You're a Neo-Nazi |date=15 August 2017 |publisher=[[Gizmodo]]}} He has frequently promoted the slogan on social media including with monetary receipts, polls, questions and memes.{{cite web |author=Brett Barrouquere |url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2017/11/16/verified-no-more-twitter-drops-blue-check-white-nationalists-accounts |title=Verified no more, Twitter drops blue check from white nationalists' accounts |date=16 November 2017 |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}}{{cite news |author=Brian Feldman |url=http://nymag.com/selectall/2017/08/baked-alaska-charlottesville-and-the-end-of-ironic-nazi.html |title=The 'Ironic Nazi' Is Coming to an End |date=14 August 2017 |publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] Magazine Intelligencer}}{{cite web |author=Jared Holt |url=http://www.rightwingwatch.org/post/alt-right-grifter-baked-alaska-is-plotting-a-comeback-on-youtube/ |title=Alt-Right Grifter 'Baked Alaska' Is Plotting A Comeback On YouTube |date=3 May 2018 |publisher=[[Right Wing Watch]]}}{{cite news |author=Jim Dalrymple II |url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/jimdalrympleii/twitter-has-permanently-banned-alt-right-figure-baked-alaska |title=Twitter Has Permanently Banned Alt-Right Troll Baked Alaska |date=15 November 2017 |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]}} *[[Craig Cobb]], an American white nationalist and separatist, created the video sharing website Podblanc and started a business named after the 14 Words,{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/individual/craig-cobb|title=Craig Cobb|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Cener}} as well as tried to start a church named after Trump which later burned to the ground.{{cite news |author=Derek Hawkins |date=24 March 2017 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/03/24/neo-nazi-bought-church-with-plans-to-name-it-after-trump-a-fire-destroyed-it/|title=Neo-Nazi bought church with plans to name it after Trump. A fire destroyed it.|publisher=The Washington Post Morning Mix blog}} *[[Ann Coulter]], an American [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] [[social criticism|social]] and [[political criticism|political]] commentator, writer, and lawyer, has been accused of promoting the slogan,{{cite news |author=Asher Schechter |url=https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/what-are-the-14-words-everyones-been-freaking-out-about-1.5482606 |title=What Are the '14 Words' Everyone's Been Freaking Out About? |date=6 January 2017 |newspaper=[[Haaretz]]}} as well as celebrated by some fans and [[white supremacists]] for allegedly doing so.{{cite news |author=Joe Vesey-Byrne |url=https://www.indy100.com/article/white-nationalists-white-supremacists-isis-internet-trolling-dylann-roof-southern-poverty-law-center-7512931 |title=Spreading hate: How white supremacists hijacked social media |date=10 January 2017 |newspaper=[[The Independent]]}} In January 2017, she tweeted "14!", which was largely answered with "88" (in reference to 14/88) on her Twitter. Coulter has claimed the tweet was regarding [[Barack Obama]]'s days left as President,{{cite news |author=Tim Marcin |url=https://www.ibtimes.com/ann-coulter-14-tweet-controversy-neo-nazis-twitter-are-excited-post-could-be-about-2470478 |title=Ann Coulter '14' Tweet Controversy: Neo-Nazis On Twitter Are Excited But Post Could Be About Obama |date=5 January 2017 |publisher=[[International Business Times]]}} which was 15 days at the time.{{cite news |author=Jenna Amatulli |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/ann-coulter-tweet_us_586e7734e4b02b5f858765ff |title=Ann Coulter Clarifies '14!' Tweet Was Reference To Obama's Presidency Ending |date=5 January 2017 |publisher=[[HuffPost]]}} *[[Harold Covington]] (September 14, 1953 – July, 2018), was an American white separatist leader and founder of the [[Northwest Territorial Imperative|Northwest Front]] organization, based on the 14 Words.{{cite news |author=Brendan Kiley |url=https://www.thestranger.com/blogs/slog/2015/06/30/22474472/dylann-roof-and-his-fascination-with-a-seattle-based-white-power-group|title=Dylann Roof and His Fascination with a Seattle-Based White Power Group|publisher=The Stranger}}{{cite web |author=Chuck Tanner |url=https://www.irehr.org/2018/07/31/harold-covington-dieswhich-way-the-northwest-front/|title=Harold Covington Dies.Which Way the Northwest Front? |publisher=IREHR|date=31 July 2018}} *[[Nathan Damigo]], an American white supremacist, leader of [[Identity Evropa]] and former [[US Marine]], supports and promotes the slogan with his organization.{{cite news |author=Isabel Vincent |url=https://nypost.com/2017/08/19/white-power-rally-organizers-are-spreading-hate-to-new-york/ |title=White power rally organizers are spreading hate to New York |date=19 August 2017 |newspaper=[[New York Post]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.adl.org/resources/profiles/identity-evropa |title=Identity Evropa |publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]]}} *[[Prussian Blue (duo)|April Gaede]], an American white nationalist and neo-Nazi stage mom, whose daughters (Prussian Blue) used to sing under [[Resistance Records]]; He has stated that he and his organization "embrace principles that will secure the existence of our people and a future for our children".{{cite magazine |author=Tina Nguyen |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/05/donald-trump-white-supremacist-delegate |title=Donald Trump's White-Supremacist Delegate May Be Here to Stay |date=11 May 2016 |magazine=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]}}{{cite news |author=Stephen Lemons |url=https://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/news/white-power-american-third-position-party-seeks-toehold-in-arizona-6499191 |title=White Power "American Third Position" Party Seeks Toehold in Arizona |date=21 May 2010 |newspaper=[[Phoenix New Times]]}} He has claimed that [[Ron Paul]] withdrew his endorsement of him for a [[Judiciary of California|judgeship in California]], after media reported that he was an advocate of the 14 Words.{{cite web |author=David Holthouse |url=https://www.mediamatters.org/blog/2011/08/03/fertile-ground-white-nationalists-organize-with/180982 |title="Fertile Ground": White Nationalists Organize Within Tea Party |date=3 August 2011 |publisher=[[Media Matters]]}} *[[David Lane (white supremacist)|David Lane]] (1938–2007), was an American white supremacist leader and key member of the terrorist organization [[The Order (white supremacist group)|The Order]]. He is credited with creating and popularizing the Fourteen Words.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/19/us/the-secret-history-of-white-power.html |title=The Secret History of White Power |date=19 May 2018 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}} The [[Anti-Defamation League|ADL]] have described Lane's slogan as reflecting "the primary white supremacist worldview in the late 20th and early 21st centuries".{{cite web|url=https://www.adl.org/education/references/hate-symbols/14-words |title=14 Words |publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]]}} *[[Stephen McNallen]], American neo-pagan leader and founder of the [[Asatru Folk Assembly]], quoted the 14 Words verbatim{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/ideology/neo-volkisch|title=Neo-Volkisch|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center}} and based his own slogan "The existence of my people is not negotiable" as a simplified 14 Words.{{cite book| first = Mattias| last = Gardell| title = Gods of the Blood: The Pagan Revival and White Separatism| page=283}} *[[Tom Metzger]], an American white separatist leader, founder of [[White Aryan Resistance]] and hosted the 14 Word writings of imprisoned David Lane; accused the United States government of murdering Lane at his death in 2007.{{cite magazine |url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2007/terrorist-14-words-author-dies-prison |title=Terrorist, '14 Words' Author, Dies in Prison |magazine=[[Intelligence Report]] |date=Fall 2007 |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}}{{cite book |author=George Michael |editor=Joshua B. Morgan |date=January 2016 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/303446060_This_is_War_Tom_Metzger_White_Aryan_Resistance_and_the_Lone_Wolf_Legacy |chapter=Chapter 3: This is War! Also, here's the secret Nazi code 14/88 a few times." |author=Cody Johnston }}{{cite news |author=Jerry Iannelli |url=https://www.miaminewtimes.com/news/florida-republican-wants-to-add-political-affiliation-to-hate-crime-list-9707608 |title=Florida State Rep. President's Adviser Writes 'Heil Hitler' Neo-Nazi Symbol on Facebook|publisher=The Real News Network}} *[[Faith Goldy]], a Canadian right-wing writer and commentator, has recited{{cite news |author=Michael Edison Hayden |url=https://www.newsweek.com/ann-coulter-trump-white-nationalist-887699 |title=Ann Coulter Retweets White Nationalist Charlotesville Leader Who Attacked Trump With Syria Conspiracy Theory |date=16 April 2018 |publisher=[[Newsweek]]}} and supported{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2017/12/21/hatewatch-headlines-12212017 |title=How badly is the Bundy case screwed up? Media gear up for voting-rights assault; Faith Goldy recites, embraces the '14 Words'; and more |date=21 December 2017 |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}} the Fourteen Words,{{cite news |author=Tom Yun |url=https://thevarsity.ca/2018/03/26/open-letter-petitions-u-of-t-to-rescind-faith-goldys-student-leadership-award/ |title=Open letter petitions U of T to rescind Faith Goldy's student leadership award |date=26 March 2018|newspaper=[[The Varsity (newspaper)|The Varsity]]}}{{cite web |author=Nick Taylor |url=http://www.trentarthur.ca/cant-welcome-faith-goldy/ |title=Why We Can't Welcome Faith Goldy |date=27 March 2018 |newspaper=[[Arthur (newspaper)|Arthur]]}} saying "I don't see that as controversial... We want to survive."{{cite news |author=Mari Uyehara |url=https://www.gq.com/story/how-free-speech-warriors-mainstreamed-white-supremacists |title=How Free Speech Warriors Mainstreamed White Supremacists |date=8 May 2018|publisher=[[GQ]]}} After being banned by [[Patreon]] for her advocacy of the slogan, Goldy defended her views, and gathered petition signatures in public on a document which replaced "white children" with "[[Aboriginal child protection|aboriginal children]]", to supposedly prove the slogan was not hate speech.{{cite web |author=Jared Holt |url=http://www.rightwingwatch.org/post/faith-goldy-defends-her-recital-of-14-words/ |title=Faith Goldy Defends Her Recital Of '14 Words' |date=29 May 2018 |publisher=[[Right Wing Watch]]}} *[[Marian Kotleba]], a Slovak politician and leader of the far-right [[Kotleba – People's Party Our Slovakia]] political party, has been accused of demonstrating support for the slogan,{{cite news |url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20881113/kotleba-of-lsns-charged-with-extremism.html |title=Kotleba of ĽSNS charged with extremism |date=30 July 2018 |newspaper=[[The Slovak Spectator]]}} with supposed reference to the Fourteen Words by making a €1,488 donation to charity,{{cite news |author=Blaise Gauquelin |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2017/08/02/le-fuhrer-slovaque-de-banska-bystrica-inquiete-par-la-justice_5167684_3210.html |title=Le " Führer " slovaque de Banska Bystrica inquiété par la justice |language=FR |trans-title=Slovak "Führer" from Banska Bystrica worried about justice |date=2 August 2017 |newspaper=[[Le Monde]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/slovak-far-right-leader-charged-with-promoting-extremism/ |title=Slovak far-right leader charged with promoting extremism |date=28 July 2018 |publisher=[[The Times of Israel]] |agency=Agence France-Presse}} which he is facing criminal charges for in Slovakia.{{cite news |author=Tatiana Jancarikova |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovakia-extremism/police-charge-leader-of-slovak-far-right-party-with-extremism-idUSKBN1AD223 |title=Police charge leader of Slovak far-right party with extremism |date=28 July 2017 |publisher=Reuters}} *[[Saga (singer)|Saga]], a Swedish white nationalist singer-songwriter, long-time supporter of the 14 Words slogan and personal friend of Lane; turned his poetry into music format and released the CD ''On My Own'' which includes the song "Goodbye [[David Lane (white nationalist)|David Lane]]", a variant of "[[Candle in the Wind]]" as part of his euology.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisissaga.com/mymusic-onmyown-lyrics.html|title=thisissaga.com|publisher=Thisisaga|accessdate=18 January 2015}}{{dead link|date=October 2018}}{{cite web |author=Edmund Standing |url=https://lemosandcrane.co.uk/resources/bnponline.pdf |title=BNP Media |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2018-09-19}} *[[Varg Vikernes]], a Norwegian [[National Socialist Black Metal]] musician and proponent of the [[white genocide conspiracy theory]] who regularly uses "14" and "88" numerology in the videos of his Thulean Perspective channel on Youtube. ==2018 United States DHS press release== In 2018, although dismissed by the US government as a coincidence,{{cite news |author=Blake Montgomery |url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/blakemontgomery/homeland-security-statement-theory |title=Homeland Security Officials Say Claims That Statement Mimics A White Supremacist Slogan Are Merely Conspiracy Theories |quote=The February press release has a 14-word title, "We Must Secure The Border And Build The Wall To Make America Safe Again", which resembles the grammatical structure of a common white supremacist slogan |date=29 June 2018 |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]}} the Trump administration's [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] were accused of referencing both "88" in a document,{{cite news |author=Aviya Kushner |url=https://forward.com/culture/404371/are-14-and-88-nazi-dog-whistles-in-this-homeland-security-document-or-just/ |title=Are '14' And '88' Nazi Dog Whistles In Border Security Document — Or Just Numbers? |date=28 June 2018 |newspaper=[[The Forward]]}} and the Fourteen Words by creating a similar fourteen-worded title,{{cite news |author= Chauncey DeVega |url=https://www.salon.com/2018/07/06/did-trump-administration-send-a-coded-signal-to-neo-nazis-maybe-not-but-is-that-reassuring/ |title=Did Trump administration send a coded signal to neo-Nazis? Maybe not — but is that reassuring? |date=6 July 2018 |publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]}} starting with the same first three words ("We must secure"), in relation to illegal immigration and border control:
We Must Secure The Border And Build The Wall To Make America Safe Again.{{cite press release |url=https://www.dhs.gov/news/2018/02/15/we-must-secure-border-and-build-wall-make-america-safe-again |title=We Must Secure The Border And Build The Wall To Make America Safe Again |quote=On average, out of 88 claims that pass the credible fear screening, fewer than 13 will ultimately result in a grant of asylum |date=15 February 2018 |publisher=[[United States Department of Homeland Security]]}}
A press release issued in February 2018 on the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|US Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS) website included a title with fourteen words similarly structured to the white supremacist phrase ("We Must Secure The Border And Build The Wall To Make America Safe Again"). The release also included a reference to the number '88' in the text: "On average, out of 88 claims that pass the credible fear screening, fewer than 13 will ultimately result in a grant of asylum." The similarity was widely shared on social media.{{cite news |last1=Kalmbacher |first1=Colin |title=Twitter Explodes After Homeland Security Headline Appears to Mimic '14-Words' Neo-Nazi Slogan |url=https://lawandcrime.com/high-profile/twitter-explodes-after-homeland-security-headline-appears-to-mimic-14-words-neo-nazi-slogan/ |work=lawandcrime.com |date=28 June 2018 |accessdate=29 June 2018}} DHS dismissed the similarity as a conspiracy theory, and journalist [[Chris Hayes]] attributed the unusual use of 88 as a statistical artifact of how DHS processes asylum seekers. == References related to terrorism and violence == [[File:CurtisAllgier.jpg|thumb|[[White power skinhead|Skinhead]] murderer [[Curtis Allgier]] has tattoos of "14" and "88"]] The slogans and numerology of "14" and "88" have been used by many white supremacists, both before and after committing violence (such as in manifestos), as well as symbolically within criminal acts. These include Order-member [[David Lane (white supremacist)|David Lane]], assassination attempters Paul Schlesselman and Daniel Cowart, and murderers [[Dylann Roof]]{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/dylann-roof-s-videotaped-confessions-stuns-courtroom-n694036|title=Dylann Roof's Videotaped Confession Stuns Courtroom |last=Siemaszko|first=Corky|date=December 9, 2016|work=[[NBCNews.com]]|accessdate=8 January 2017}} and [[Curtis Allgier]].{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/680194690/Tattoos-tell-a-tale-of-intimidation.html|title=Tattoos tell a tale of intimidation |last=Reavy |first=Pat |date=June 28, 2007|work=[[Deseret News]]|accessdate=8 January 2017}} Allgier has "14" and "88" tattooed on his forehead above and to the sides of the words "skin" and "head" above his eyes in his mugshot. === Murder of Alan Berg === {{Main article|Alan Berg}} The assassination of [[Jewish]] talk show host [[Alan Berg]] in June 1984, is considered as [[The Order (white supremacist group)|The Order]]'s most infamous act of terrorism. Order member Bruce Pierce served as the gunman in the murder and Lane the getaway driver.{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2010/08/18/death-assassin-order's-bruce-pierce-dies-prison|title=Hatewatch|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2007/terrorist-14-words-author-dies-prison |title=Terrorist, '14 Words' Author, Dies in Prison |date=1 October 2017 |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}} During Lane's imprisonment on separate convictions (some relating to violating Alan Berg's civil rights) he created the Fourteen Words slogan. The number 14 continues to symbolize allegiance to the [[Aryan Nations]]' vision of a [[Northwest Territorial Imperative|white homeland]].{{cite web |author=Meagan Day |date=4 November 2016 |url=https://timeline.com/white-supremacist-rural-paradise-fb62b74b29e0 |title=Welcome to Hayden Lake, where white supremacists tried to build their homeland |publisher=Timeline}} === Barack Obama assassination plot === {{Main article|Barack Obama assassination plot in Tennessee}} "14/88" numerology was symbolically included in the [[Barack Obama]] assassination plot in October 2008. Both Neo-Nazis, Schlesselman and Cowart were introduced to each other online by a mutual friend who shared their white supremacist beliefs.{{cite news|url=http://archive.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2008/10/28/skinhead_plot_news_sweeps_suspects_tenn_hometown/|title=Authorities say skinhead plot wasn't fully formed|last1=Baird|first1=Woody|date=2008-10-30|newspaper=[[Associated Press]] |last2=DeMillo |first2=Andrew |accessdate=2017-11-29}} Within a month of meeting, they had planned to kill the Democratic Party nominee by driving at their target and shooting from their vehicle. This was to be followed by a killing spree in which the men planned to kill 88 [[African American]]s, 14 of whom were to be beheaded. They were targeting mostly children at an unidentified, predominantly [[Black people|black]] school.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/28/us/politics/28plot.html?scp=1&sq=Daniel%20Cowart&st=cse|title=Arrests in plan to kill Obama and black schoolchildren|last=Lichtblau|first=Eric|date=2008-10-27|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |author-link=Eric Lichtblau |accessdate=2008-10-28}} Shortly after their arrest, their vehicle was discovered to have "14" and "88" written onto it. === Wisconsin Sikh temple shooting === {{Main article|Wisconsin Sikh temple shooting}} Mass-shooter [[Wade Michael Page]], who killed six and wounded four members of the [[Sikhism in the United States|Sikh community]] in August 2012, had been a supporter of the Fourteen Words, and was found with "14" onto a [[Celtic Cross]] tattooed on his arm,{{cite news |author=Adam Weinstein |url=https://www.motherjones.com/crime-justice/2012/08/wade-michael-page-tattoos-sikh-temple-shooting/ |title=The Sikh Temple Shooter's Racist Tattoos, Deciphered |date=6 August 2012 |publisher=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]}} after committing suicide at the scene of the crime.{{cite news |author=Matthew Goodwin |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/aug/08/wade-michael-page-violent-far-right |title=Wade Michael Page and the rise of violent far-right extremism |date=8 August 2012 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}{{cite news |author=Abby Rogers |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-made-wade-michael-page-racist-2012-8 |title=Wade Michael Page Became A Radical Racist In The US Army |date=10 August 2012 |publisher=[[Business Insider]]}} About a year before the shooting, Page wrote on the Internet regarding the slogan, "Passive submission is indirect support to the oppressors. Stand up for yourself and live the 14 words."{{cite news |author=Russell Goldman |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/wisconsin-gunman-wade-michael-pages-tattoos-racist-beliefs/story?id=16949676 |title=Cracking Wisconsin Gunman's Secret Racist Tattoo Code |date=7 August 2012 |publisher=[[ABC News]]}} === Charleston church shooting === {{Main article|Charleston church massacre}} After the Charleston mass-murder shooting in June 2015, [[Dylann Roof]]'s ideology and apparent manifesto emerged in the media with multiple references to "1488",{{cite news |author=Clara Jeffery |author2=James West |url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2015/06/references-dylann-roof-manifesto-explained-1488/ |title=The Deeply Racist References in Dylann Roof's Apparent Manifesto, Decoded. |date=20 June 2015 |publisher=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]}} these included several photos of Roof pictured alongside the numbers.{{cite news |author=Rob Crilly |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/11689037/Charleston-church-massacre-Things-we-learned-from-shooter-Dylann-Roofs-racist-manifesto.html |title=Charleston church massacre: Things we learned from shooter Dylann Roof's racist manifesto |date=21 June 2015 |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}} He symbolically brought 88 bullets to the [[Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church]] to carry out the shooting, in which nine [[African Americans]] were killed.{{cite news |author=AJ Willingham |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/02/21/us/hate-symbols-changing-trnd/index.html |title=These are the new symbols of hate |date=22 February 2017 |publisher=CNN}}{{cite news |author=Tonya Maxwell |author2=Tim Smith |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/01/10/dylann-roof-sentencing/96412218/ |title=Federal jury sentences Dylann Roof to death |date=11 January 2017 |newspaper=[[USA Today]]}} === Pittsburgh synagogue shooting === {{Main article|Pittsburgh synagogue shooting}} Robert Bowers, the gunman suspected of killing 11 people and wounding 6 at the Tree of Life Synagogue in [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania, included the numeric code "1488" in the header image of his [[Gab (social network)|Gab]] social media account.{{cite news|url=https://heavy.com/news/2018/10/robert-bowers-social-media-rob-gab|title=Robert Bowers: See Squirrel Hill Suspect's Social Media|date=October 27, 2018|publisher=Heavy.com}}https://www.thedailybeast.com/robert-bowers-is-neo-nazi-who-posted-about-killing-jews-on-gab Bowers also expressed [[Christian Identity]] rhetoric declaring "the lord jesus christ is come in the flesh" while espousing anti-Semitic views that "jews are children of satan".{{cite news |author1=Katie Zezima |author2=Wesley Lowery |date=October 27, 2018 |title=Suspected synagogue shooter appears to have railed against Jews, refugees online |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/amphtml/national/suspected-synagogue-shooter-appears-to-have-railed-against-jews-refugees-online/2018/10/27/e99dd282-da18-11e8-a10f-b51546b10756_story.html}} ==See also== * [[Northwest Territorial Imperative]] * [[White genocide conspiracy theory]] * [[White separatism]] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Neo-fascism]] [[Category:Neo-Nazism]] [[Category:Slogans]] [[Category:White nationalist symbols]]

revision.comment: Cleaned up Arabic transliterations (still could use work), added bits of info from the second English-language Wikipedia entry on this holiday (wiki/Garangao) so that the smaller, redundant entry can be deleted.
revision.text:
[[File:Gargee'an in Ahwaz 02.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Gargee'an celebration in [[Contemporary Arts Museum of Ahvaz]].]] '''Gargee'an''' ({{lang-ar|قرقيعان}}), sometimes spelled as '''Gerga'oon''' (Arabic: قرقاعون), is a semiannual<ref>Sometimes the holiday is only celebrated annually, during the month of Ramadan.</ref> celebration, observed primarily in [[Eastern Arabia]] ([[Arab states of the Persian Gulf]]), [[Iraq]], and the [[Khuzestan Province|Khuzestan region]] in [[Iran]]. It takes place on the 15th night of the [[Islamic month]] of [[Sha'ban]] and on the 15th night of [[Ramadan]]. Gargee'an is marked with children dressing in traditional attire and going door-to-door to receive [[sweets]] and [[nut (fruit)|nut]]s from neighbours, whilst also singing traditional songs. The tradition has existed for hundreds of years and deeply rooted in [[Culture of Eastern Arabia|Gulf culture]].<ref name=BNA>{{cite news|title=القرقاعون من أهم الاحتفالات الرمضانية الشعبية في مملكة البحرين|url=http://www.bna.bh/portal/news/519354|accessdate=3 February 2013|newspaper=[[Bahrain News Agency]]|date=2 August 2012}}</ref>
Although the celebration of Gargee'an shares superficial similarities with the [[Halloween]] custom of [[trick-or-treating]], practiced in some western countries, Gargee'an has no connection with horror and no associated origin with Halloween.
== Etymology and Alternative Names == The exact origin of the word ''Qarqī'ān'' is unknown though several theories exist; One such theory states that it is derived from ''Qarqa'ah'' ({{lang-ar|قرقعة}}), which means ''click'' or ''snick'', the sound of iron pots carrying the sweets hitting each other while serving the sweets.<ref name=BNA/> Another theory says that it could originate from the kids of [[Medina]] singing "Qarrat Al-'Ain, Qarrat Al-'Ain" ([[Arabic]]: قرة العين) which was changed with time to ''Qarqī'ān''.
The holiday is also known by several different names in each region: Majeena or Karkiaan in [[Iraq]], Garangao or Garangaou in [[Qatar]] and [[Bahrain]], Karkee'aan or Qariqaan in [[Saudi Arabia]], Gargee'aan in [[Kuwait]], Garangashoch, At-Tablah or Qarnakosh in [[Oman]], and Hag Al Leylah in [[the UAE]].
==Religious significance== Both Gerga'oon nights are significant to both Sunni and [[Shia]] Muslims. Gerga'oon on the 15th of Sha'ban marks the birthday of Imam [[Muhammad al-Mahdi]], the 12th [[Imamah (Shia doctrine)|Imam]].<ref>{{cite news|title="نسائية سار الرياضي" تقيم مهرجان القرقاعون الأول|url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/2170/news/read/162488/1.html|accessdate=4 February 2013|newspaper=Al Wasat|date=15 August 2008}}</ref> Gerga'oon on the 15th of Ramadan coincides with the birth of Imam [[Hasan ibn Ali]], the second Imam in [[Shia Islam]]. As a result, the occasion is seen as a time of happiness and festivities by Shia Muslims, particularly in [[Bahrain]].<ref name=Wasat>{{cite news|title=القرقاعون: البحرين تحيي ليلة النصف من رمضان|url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/75/news/read/122551/1.html|accessdate=3 February 2013|newspaper=Al Wasat|date=20 November 2002}}</ref> Events during the night include religious sermons conducted by [[mosque]]s, [[carnival]]-like attractions in much of the capital cities of the Persian Gulf region, such as in [[Manama]] and [[Doha]].<ref name=Wasat/>
==Tradition== Children gather in small [[choir]] groups in front of a home and sing. The song is intended to call on [[Allah|God]] to bless the youngest child of the family, to keep him or her healthy that the mother will remain happy. The more they sing, the more nuts and sweets they receive. The Qarqee'an tradition is intended to spread love, happiness and affection among adults and children.
In modern times, supermarkets, corporates, and malls compete to attract children during this time via advertising in newspapers and on TV, and by offering special promotions and arranging closed Qarqee'an events to market themselves.<ref>{{cite news|title="البحرين سيتي سنتر" يحتفل بليلة القرقاعون مساء اليوم|url=http://www.alayam.com/newsdetails.aspx?id=86247|accessdate=3 February 2013|newspaper=Al Ayam|date=31 July 2012}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Culture of Eastern Arabia]] *[[Culture of Bahrain]] *[[Culture of Kuwait]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://e.gov.kw/News/KUNAMoreNews_Eng.aspx?NewsId=58396 Kuwaiti government statement]
{{Ramadan|state=expanded}}
